answers.answer: Dear Rene01:  The duration and schedule for chemotherapy was determined based on research.  That is, in large groups of people, a particular regimen was superior to another.  In an individual, it is impossible to say whether there will be any repercussions from three vs. four cycles.  I am certain that your physicians are monitoring your organ function, including your liver and kidneys, although these drugs tend to be more toxic to other organs.  It is uncommon to stop chemo before completion except in the very frail.  Usually, the only reasons chemo would be stopped early is patient is too ill (not usually just from side effects - this usually results in dose reduction), a major complication has occurred, the cancer progresses, or the patient decides not to continue.  Ultimately, it is your choice, but I would recommend a very frank discussion with your doctor first.  Perhaps these side effects could be better managed.

question: I am an early stage breast cancer patient (neg lymph nodes, 1.4 cm tumor, ER+, Her2+, grade 3) who has completed three of four rounds of A/C chemo.  The effects of the chemo (and possibly the side effect meds) have been very harsh (my oncologist says less than 10% of her Northwestern U patients have as severe a reaction).  I have been very sick with each chemo on average for 14 days following the treatment.  I was hospitalized for fever and neutrepenia for four days during my second round.  Given how harsh the chemo has been on my body, given that my lymph nodes were negative, and that I am a candidate for tamoxifen which will stop the growth of remaining cancer cells, I am seriously considering passing on the fourth chemo.  I am very worried about long term side effects.  My "body" intuition is that my liver or kidneys may be getting damaged in the process. I also am concerned about possible onset of diabetes (I appear to have the key symptoms and will be requesting a blood test). My questions are 1) what are the risks vs. benefits of the fourth chemo; 2) what questions should I be asking my oncologist; and 3) is it common to stop chemo before completion and under what conditions?  Thanks very much.
title: Risks of Fourth Chemo
